Considering the publication date of 1658, it's important to note that plays often take inspiration from contemporary or past significant events. In the mid-17th century, Europe was experiencing various conflicts, including the Thirty Years' War (1618–1648) and other related wars. Hungary at that time was part of the Habsburg Monarchy after being conquered in the early 17th century.

The title suggests a tragi-comedy about Théodore, Queen of Hungary. This might refer to historical figures or events around that period. The mention of a queen implies it's set in a royal court, possibly involving political intrigue or conflicts of the time. So, the timeframe could be during the early 17th century when Hungary was under Habsburg rule.

As for the location, since the play is about Théodore and set in Hungary, the primary location would likely be Hungary itself. The historical context ties it to the period when Hungary was part of the Holy Roman Empire or during the Counter-Reformation efforts, which were significant in the early to mid-17th century.
